data.title: Tiara of the Month: Queen Sirikit of Thailand’s Floral Ruby Bandeau
data.meta_description: Queen Sirikit wore the dazzling diadem on a Royal Tour in the 1960s
data.text:
In 1960, Queen Sirikit of Thailand embarked on a global royal tour with a bespoke wardrobe made exclusively for her by Balmain. The tour included a visit to the Vatican to meet Pope John XXIII, celebrating the kinship of Buddhist and Roman Catholic traditions. For this, Queen Sirikit donned a white diamond and ruby bandeau known as the Floral Ruby Bandeau. She wore the glamorous diadem around a chic up-do and accompanying lace veil, along with a string of elegant pearls around her neck.

Featuring gems styled as individual flowers, each escalating in size and culminating in a prominent central ruby, the bandeau is a tiara which sits across the top of the head. According to The Court Jeweller, sources suggest that the central ruby stone at its centre is interchangeable.

Queen Sirikit also wore the tiara again in 1960 for a grand state banquet in Belgium, hosted by King Baudouin of Belgium at the Royal Palace of Brussels. During the visit, Queen Sirikit paired the tiara with diamond earrings and a glittering diamond necklace with a pendant. Draped across her was an elegant sash, secured with a diamond brooch. Only a month prior to this, the King of Belgium had announced his engagement to Spanish aristocrat Fabiola de Mora y Aragon, who became Queen Fabiola of Belgium.

Queen Sirikit was born in 1932, the eldest daughter of Prince Kitiyakara, the Thai Ambassador to the United Kingdom and later France. Whilst studying in Paris, 15-year-old Sirikit met King Bhumibol Adulyadej of Thailand. He had been enthroned King Rama IX unexpectedly following the abdication of his childless uncle in 1935 and death of his eldest brother from an unexplained gunshot wound in 1946.

Sirikit visited the King regularly during his recuperation from a serious car accident and they married in 1950, just one week before his re-scheduled coronation. Their reign was popular and long, lasting 70 years and 126 days – the length of which has only been surpassed by King Louis XIV of France and Queen Elizabeth II. The King had 30 different prime ministers, survived numerous military coups, and managed a reported US$30 billion bank account. If true, this would make him the richest monarch. The Thai Crown Jewels include the 545-carat Golden Jubilee brown diamond, the largest cut diamond in the world.

King Bhumibol Adulyadej of Thailand died in October 2016 and Queen Sirikit, now 90, has largely retreated from public duties. The crown passed to their son King Vajiralongkorn in 2016, known as Rama X. Lèse Majesté in Thailand forbids criticism of the monarch but Vajiralongkorn’s reign has been hailed as a less formal one by certain publications, citing his extravagant lifestyle and eccentric ways a distraction: he threw a four-day funeral for his beloved poodle known as ‘Air Chief Marshal Fufu’.
